Yes, breaking a coconut is a common practice during traditional Hindu funeral ceremonies. The coconut is seen as a symbol of the human head, which is believed to contain the soul or the consciousness of the deceased. Therefore, breaking the coconut is considered to represent the breaking of the physical body and the release of the soul from the mortal form.

The coconut is also associated with Lord Ganesha, who is revered as the remover of obstacles and the god of wisdom and intelligence in Hinduism. Breaking the coconut is believed to symbolize invoking Ganesha's blessings and seeking his grace to ease the transition of the soul to the afterlife.

During the funeral ceremony, a priest or a family member will take a coconut and break it on a hard surface, such as a rock or pavement, while reciting Vedic verses and offering prayers. The broken pieces of the coconut are then gathered and offered to the gods as a symbol of respect and gratitude.

Overall, the practice of breaking a coconut is an important and symbolic part of the Hindu funeral ceremony that represents the release of the soul and the seeking of divine blessings for the departed soul's journey to the afterlife.
